messages.content: <QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë aheai</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë aheai</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the sun is rising</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>The sun rises</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë aheo</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë aheo</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the sun is setting</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pei yoka ha a ahetou tëhë a husi koikoimoma</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pei yoka ha a ahetou tëhë a husi koikoimoma</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing with the puppy</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Children small the puppy with the play play</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë yesi kë iha a ahetou</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pë yesi kë iha a ahetou</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you should go and get some bananas</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>I</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>I house new I make</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>hãtõ ya nahiki aheamai kuprei</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>hãtõ ya nahiki aheamai kuprei</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing in the river</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Children the river in playing</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>warë këki aheare kë thë</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>warë këki aheare kë thë</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing in the sun</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë ki napë no wãri ahepi ma rë mai</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë ki napë no wãri ahepi ma rë mai</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the sun is very hot today and I</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ira kë a wãri ahetetou totihio tëhë, a mori niyãõ tëhë, ikãri a shëi shoaoma</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>ira kë a wãri ahetetou totihio tëhë, a mori niyãõ tëhë, ikãri a shëi shoaoma</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>When you go to the forest, be careful not to get lost, and bring back some fruit</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>yëtu kë yamaki rë mi ãmõãhãrayopërei</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>yëtu kë yamaki rë mi ãmõãhãrayopërei</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you should not go to the village alone</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You not go village alone should</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>rë ahetepraruhe</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>rë ahetepraruhe</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are a good person</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>te meteré (lit. te plans ho ko re w ë</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>te meteré (lit. te plans ho ko re w ë</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>I am hungry</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>My stomach is empty</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>rë henaopoi (cha.)</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>rë henaopoi (cha.)</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are beautiful (woman)</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You beautiful (woman)</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>hei ya shikãpi rë rëre hami</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>hei ya shikãpi rë rëre hami</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are a good hunter</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You good hunter are</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>hei ai yoka rë horere</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>hei ai yoka rë horere</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the child is playing outside</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Child outside play is doing</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pata ma rë tirorotamayoruu tharei</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pata ma rë tirorotamayoruu tharei</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing in the river</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>children the river in playing are</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>rë uprayahi ha</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>rë uprayahi ha</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are a good person</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>yaro kahiki rë keonowei thë yãno pë si ahi nikerei</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>yaro kahiki rë keonowei thë yãno pë si ahi nikerei</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing in the village plaza under the hot sun</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>wa rii ha rãrini ãhi teshi ta thapa</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>wa rii ha rãrini ãhi teshi ta thapa</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>I</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ama ãsi</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ama ãsi</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>my mother</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>yëtu kë thë urihi ahetetaremam a h e</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>yëtu kë thë urihi ahetetaremam a h e</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing in the river</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>children the river in playing are</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>yëtu thë urihi ahetetai rë kõrãyouwei, puhipuhi pëni (mit.)</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>yëtu thë urihi ahetetai rë kõrãyouwei, puhipuhi pëni (mit.)</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>The children are playing and running around the house, they are very happy (myth)</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Children the house around run play, very happy (myth)</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë henaki ha ahetetamarini, henaki wakë piyëmakema, pothothe , yopri puu naki hisikikema</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë henaki ha ahetetamarini, henaki wakë piyëmakema, pothothe , yopri puu naki hisikikema</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>The sun is high in the sky, the sun</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë përia ahetea</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pë përia ahetea</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are a good person</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>warë kë ki hiraa ahetea</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>warë kë ki hiraa ahetea</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing outside</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>children the outside play</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>wa ahetepraa totihia kë a kure</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>wa ahetepraa totihia kë a kure</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>I</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>yoka ãhiãi</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>yoka ãhiãi</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>good morning</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë mi titi</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë mi titi</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the sun is hot</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ãimawë no wãri kë ki huhehea waikirayonowë, pëhëki yashuprai waikirayou kë a kuhe (cha.)</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>ãimawë no wãri kë ki huhehea waikirayonowë, pëhëki yashuprai waikirayou kë a kuhe (cha.)</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>The children are playing in the river, splashing water at each other (laughing)</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Children the river in playing splashing water each other at (laughing)</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ãiwëni hoya kë a wai tharei kuroi</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ãiwëni hoya kë a wai tharei kuroi</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>The woman is cooking banana soup for the children</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Woman banana soup for children cooking</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ãiwë a wãri iha kamiyë ya roo aheteo</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ãiwë a wãri iha kamiyë ya roo aheteo</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>The children are playing in the river with their friends</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>yei kë ãmo wai wãnipraa kure</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>yei kë ãmo wai wãnipraa kure</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>let</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ãiãmori pë sherekapi si roo yaiokiri (cha.)</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ãiãmori pë sherekapi si roo yaiokiri (cha.)</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>The children are playing in the village (outside)</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Children the village in play (outside)</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>kirii hami wa wã wãri yaimopë, ihi namo wayu ha ãiãmoriwë a ta tarari</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>kirii hami wa wã wãri yaimopë, ihi namo wayu ha ãiãmoriwë a ta tarari</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>Yesterday I went to the river to fish, but I didn</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Yesterday I go river fish, but no fish catch come back empty-handed</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ei kõpina nari pë rë ãiãmorãti, a huu ta mi (wayamou, diálogo ceremonial.)</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>ei kõpina nari pë rë ãiãmorãti, a huu ta mi (wayamou, diálogo ceremonial.)</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>This is the story of our ancestors, the wayamou ceremonial dialogue</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>This story ancestors our tell, wayamou ceremonial dialogue</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>himo kë ki ãiãmoprou ha kuparuni (cha.)</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>himo kë ki ãiãmoprou ha kuparuni (cha.)</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>my child is crying because he/she is hungry</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>My child crying because hungry (diminutive)</LITERAL>

<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ãiãmo hena(ki) ... La planta se pone a secar y las hojas se pulverizan, luego se inhala el polvo, solo o mezclado, como alucinógeno.</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>ãiãmo hena(ki) ... La planta se pone a secar y las hojas se pulverizan, luego se inhala el polvo, solo o mezclado, como alucinógeno.</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>The plant is dried and the leaves are powdered, then the powder is inhaled, either alone or mixed, as a hallucinogen</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>aka ha hõprarini a wã tetea pëa</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>aka ha hõprarini a wã tetea pëa</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>I</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>I go to river fish bring</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>aka moyepi kë thë</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>aka moyepi kë thë</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the child is eating banana</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>child banana eating is</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>aka hõprai</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>aka hõprai</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>good morning</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pei kë ma pë pata namo shirikiopë hami shamariwë a pata akatahu yapikirariyoma (mit.)</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pei kë ma pë pata namo shirikiopë hami shamariwë a pata akatahu yapikirariyoma (mit.)</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>Don</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Don</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>akrëhë akrëtëai</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>akrëhë akrëtëai</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>I</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë hena pë ta yototoamapotuhe</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë hena pë ta yototoamapotuhe</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing outside</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>The children outside play</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ya thë u ha koarini</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ya thë u ha koarini</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>I</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ya thë pouku wãri ha totihiarini</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ya thë pouku wãri ha totihiarini</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are going to cook the banana in the pot</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You banana pot in cook will</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pei thë u aheteprao ha yairini</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pei thë u aheteprao ha yairini</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing in the river</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Children the river in playing are</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë no ha tetetaruni a kõrãyõma</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë no ha tetetaruni a kõrãyõma</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing in the village</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>The children play in village</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë ta shëyëpa</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë ta shëyëpa</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the sun is setting</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë hipëpema</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë hipëpema</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the sun is setting</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë thë pë puﬁ wãri hore tikrohai si ihehewë</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>pë thë pë puﬁ wãri hore tikrohai si ihehewë</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you should not go out alone in the forest at night</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You you not go forest night danger animal bad</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>thë ki ta këprari, pei kë siki</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>thë ki ta këprari, pei kë siki</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the sun is hot today, let</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë thë patherio kõõpë kë</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pë thë patherio kõõpë kë</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are a good hunter</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You the hunter good are</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>preyura kë pëni pë thë haromai totihio tharei</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>preyura kë pëni pë thë haromai totihio tharei</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing in the river with their friends</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Children the river in the friends with playing</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>he pëprai</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>he pëprai</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>it</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Rain falls</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>fimiki pëo</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>fimiki pëo</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>good morning</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë owëai tëhë pë yãrimou kãi hiraoma</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pë owëai tëhë pë yãrimou kãi hiraoma</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you should go to the river and catch some fish for us</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You go river you catch fish for us</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>warapawë yawëroopë, wa pë maikaprari</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>warapawë yawëroopë, wa pë maikaprari</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>My friend, I</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë shëi mai kë thë</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pë shëi mai kë thë</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are a good person</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You person good be that</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë no tarema</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pë no tarema</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are a good person</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë puhii</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pë puhii</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are good</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë mii mi huma</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pë mii mi huma</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you are eating banana</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>kuo pëo</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>kuo pëo</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>good morning</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>horehore p∫∫ kë nahe wãri thatathatapia ha pëkini</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>horehore p∫∫ kë nahe wãri thatathatapia ha pëkini</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing and running around the village</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Children small village around run-run-REDUP and play</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ya mishiã mrai yaio pëa</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ya mishiã mrai yaio pëa</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>give me some banana fruit</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You banana fruit give me</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>pë ha prawëpë ha f–pramopë ha</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>pë ha prawëpë ha f–pramopë ha</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>you go to the river and bathe</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You go river bathe</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>hotho pë tërëkou</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>hotho pë tërëkou</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the child is crying</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>e naha thë pë imiki rë hurukanowei, thë pë ãhã rë yehipore</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>e naha thë pë imiki rë hurukanowei, thë pë ãhã rë yehipore</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>You should not go near the river, there are many piranhas there</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>You not should river to go near, there piranha many are</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>shee pë shirõ yãmonashi uku</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>shee pë shirõ yãmonashi uku</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the child is playing with a small stick</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>child with stick small playing is</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>opo si ãikiwë kë a wai amishiri yakarema (mit.)</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>opo si ãikiwë kë a wai amishiri yakarema (mit.)</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>my friend, you should not go to that dangerous place</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Friend my, you not go place dangerous that (myth)</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama (mit.) (habla del sur del Orinoco.)</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama (mit.) (habla del sur del Orinoco.)</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the shaman is singing the chant to call the spirits of the forest</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>shaman sing chant call spirits forest (myth) (speech from south of Orinoco River)</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>decilla del demonio õmãyãri apenas se escucha</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>decilla del demonio õmãyãri apenas se escucha</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the demon</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>demon</LITERAL>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ãmoku nini</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ãmoku nini</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>my child</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ãmoku niniprou</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ãmoku niniprou</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>my friend</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>ãmoku ninimou</YANOMAMI></QUERY>
<YANOMAMI>ãmoku ninimou</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>my friend</TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: <YANOMAMI>rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama</YANOMAMI></QUERY>

<YANOMAMI>rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama</YANOMAMI> <TRANSLATION>the children are playing and running around the village</TRANSLATION> <LITERAL>Children the village around running playing</LITERAL>
